title: What are the sources of oxygen? - Quora

response.answer_text: Silem's answer is very good, I'll just elaborate a little bit. Like Silem said Oxygen originates in stars. Oxygen was not present in the very early universe before stars formed, only Hydrogen, Helium and a small amount of Lithium condensed out of the hot early universe. Oxygen comes from massive stars that have fused these three components of the early universe into heavier elements like Oxygen. When these massive stars explode, they disperse heavier elements in clouds of gas and dust. The dust and gas clouds that formed our solar system were enriched with material from earlier massive stars that had exploded. That's how oxygen came to be part of the earth. Free oxygen in the atmosphere though, comes from photosynthesis. Oxygen is a very active element, it wants to combine with other elements. So the oxygen that was part of the earth's formation was in the form of chemical compounds like: Water, Carbon Dioxide, Silicates, Iron oxide, etc. it was almost never in it's "free" uncombined form. Photosynthesis frees oxygen that's combined with Hydrogen as Water, as Silem shows in his chemical equation. But for the first 2 Billion years the earth's early atmosphere had virtually no free oxygen in it. So it took photosynthesis by living organisms to create the free oxygen rich atmosphere that we now have on earth. These organisms that first used photosynthesis are called cyanobacteria. They don't need oxygen to live they just produce oxygen as a by-product of their biological energy making process. Bacteria that don’t need oxygen are called anaerobic bacteria. Starting about 3 Billion years ago cyanobacteria began converting the earth's atmosphere from having no oxygen, to having the 21% oxygen we have today. This was called: "The Great Oxygenation Event" (GOE). Eventually other more complex organisms incorporated cyanobacteria symbiotically into themselves, these symbiotic cyanobacteria became the chloroplasts in plants, this is the part of the plant that actually carries out photosynthesis. The oxygen the cyanobacteria produced was toxic to the other anaerobic life that was living on the earth at the time. There was a huge extinction of many of these other anaerobic single celled organisms as a result of the introduction of oxygen to the atmosphere. although some of these early anaerobic bacteria survived and are with us today. But it gave rise to other forms of life that use the atmospheric oxygen biologically to make energy, a process called “aerobic respiration”. One of the organisms that has benefited from this is us: humans.

Phytoplankton. Half of all the oxygen on Earth is produced by phytoplankton — microalgae growing in the upper few meters of the ocean (the photic zone). Approximately a quarter is made by kelp and other marine macro-plants and a quarter is made by all terrestrial sources.  On land, the biggest producer of oxygen are the tropical rain forests (40.8%) followed by tropical grasslands (31%) followed by croplands (14.8%) and all other sources. I’m not sure where journalists get the oft-quoted figure that the Amazon makes 20% of the Earth’s oxygen. It can’t possibly, since all tropical forests make up only 40.8% of 25% or10%. Still, this is something we should pay attention to. Like anything else in life, Earth has an oxygen budget. The oxygen in our atmosphere is the sum of all the oxygen produced less all that is consumed. Mostly because of industrialization and the combustion of fossil fuels, the planet has had an oxygen deficient for about a century, and it’s growing rapidly. Don’t freak out though. Current projections are that by the end of the century the concentration of oxygen will drop from the current level of 20.946% to 20.825%. That’s not likely to be particularly harmful, and by then we will be mostly out of fossil fuels to burn, like it or not.  If you like science, you might enjoy my free award-winning scifi sampler.

Oxygen is the third most abundant element by mass in the universe behind hydrogen and helium. Don’t get too exited. Helium is 23 times more abundant; hydrogen is 71 times as much. Oxygen is followed by carbon, neon, iron, nitrogen, silicon, magnesium, and sulfur — in that order. All these elements are made inside stars. On Earth oxygen is the most common element on its surface of land and seas. Oxygen is so reactive that it would disappear into Earth’s oceans and soils were it not continuously replaced in the atmosphere by the photosynthesis of plants, algae, and cyanobacteria, which make oxygen from sunlight and carbon-dioxide—a heavy gas that hugs Earth’s surface to keep plants alive. Cold water holds free oxygen more easily than warm; it’s why the biodiversity of oxygen dependent life is greater in northern oceans. If Earth’s oxygen producing forests ever die, the atmosphere will quickly become depleted of oxygen; the depletion will kill all land-based, oxygen-dependent life including humans who don’t carry oxygen tanks to breathe. Oxygen-dependent ocean life will continue to survive. Loss of oxygen in the atmosphere is one of 25 or so significant extinction-precipitating events we must avoid to save ourselves and Earth where we must live. The good news is that atmospheric oxygen-loss is not in the top ten list of bad things most likely to happen. RISK

There is only one source on earth. Photosynthesis. Elementally, (in the universe) oxygen is formed within the stars as they fuse protons. Three Helium nuclei combine to form Carbon. One more Helium then combines with this Carbon to form Oxygen. Fusing carbon requires a temperature of about one billion degrees! Most of the heavy elements, from oxygen up through iron, are thought to be produced in stars that contain at least ten times as much matter as our Sun. This process is referred to as the catalytic CNO cycle. Heavier elements, that come after iron, are produced during supernovas. Oxygen is earth’s most abundant element comprising 49% by weight of our planet if you exclude the inner iron core. It is 30% of our planet in total weight if you include the iron core. However, free oxygen is not released by earth’s mantle into the atmosphere, and volcanoes do not produce free oxygen as it is too reactive an element and is easily stored away. Free atmospheric oxygen therefore, comes about because of oxygen released by photosynthesis only. This is the surprising answer to the above question. The only source o free atmospheric oxygen is photosynthesis. So trees and land plants together are contributing to a quarter of the earth’s oxygen. Phytoplankton, cyanobacteria, algae and kelp in the oceans produce three quarters of earth’s oxygen, about 75%. So these photosynthetic living things are the source of Free Oxygen in the atmosphere. So there is only ONE source of free Oxygen and that is photosynthesis. We have 1,200,000,000,000,000,000 kg of Free Oxygen in our Atmosphere. Total Oxygen which is 30%, (almost 1/3rd the weight of our planet), of total earth’s weight is 1,791,600,000, 000,000,000,000,000 kg Oxygen molecules on Earth So the % (percentage) of free atmospheric oxygen out of all the oxygen in our planet is only 0.000067% !!!! We do not fully understand the mechanism by which the free atmospheric oxygen appears to stabilise around the 21% mark. Unless the planet is extremely wet, very, very wet, the percentage of oxygen may not creep upwards as oxygen is very reactive and trees and other things will start spontaneously catching fire. I digress. Hopefully, I have given you a full answer :) Thanks for reading.

Free oxygen in the atmosphere comes almost exclusively from photosynthesis. Oxygen is the third-most abundant element in the universe, so there’s no shortage of the element on Earth; however, most of it is locked up in compounds like water and minerals. That’s because oxygen is highly reactive. On a lifeless planet, you wouldn’t expect a high concentration of free oxygen in the environment. When life evolved the ability to photosynthesize, it started to produce O[math]_2[/math] as a waste product. The basic equation is: 6CO[math]_2[/math] + 6H[math]_2[/math]O → C[math]_6[/math]H[math]_{12}[/math]O[math]_6[/math] + 6O[math]_2[/math] Obviously the real process is much more complicated, as it involves many enzymes and intermediary products, but that’s not relevant right now. The first photosynthesizers produced free oxygen faster than it could react with the other elements in the environment; in fact, the so-called oxygen catastrophe killed a lot of organisms whose metabolism was not able to deal with such an excess of oxygen. Eventually, every exposed surface that was capable of reacting with oxygen had been duly oxidized, and the excess started to accumulate in the air and water. And that’s where the current O[math]_2[/math] in the atmosphere comes from. Side note: Scientists think they could determine whether an alien planet has life by looking for the spectral signature of free oxygen in the planet’s atmosphere. A large quantity of free oxygen would not be expected on a lifeless world.

There was no oxygen in Earth’s early atmosphere. At least not in molecular form—it was there as CO2, H2O, any amount of compounds, and arrived that way with comets, asteroids and planetesimals as the planet was formed. The oxygen came later, in what is known as the Great Oxygenation Event (which sounds like it took a weekend, but in reality took millions of years). That oxygen came from algae living in the oceans. They released it gradually over a very long time, but most of it reacted with rocks—oxygen is actually one of the most reactive gases we know of; the only reason we don’t see it ordinarily is that it has already reacted with almost anything on the Earth that it can react with. Finally, all rocks had reacted and oxygen started to build up in the atmosphere. This probably led to a huge mass extinction—oxygen was a deadly poison to almost anything alive at the time, but we have no trace of it as it only affected microorganisms and they don’t fossilise well. We, and almost everything else alive today, are descendants of the few survivors: organisms that evolved to tolerate oxygen, and even to require it.

Where does the majority of oxygen come from? Assuming that most of the primordial nucleosynthesis hypothesesassociated with the Lambda-CDM“standard cosmological model” are correct … Short answer: All — not only “the majority of” — oxygen ultimately “comes from” stellar nucleosynthesis,from fusion reactions deep inside stars. If the question refers to oxygen first bound by oxidationto other elements, then again being “liberated” by some other chemical reaction occurring here on Earth: Short answer: From photosynthesis. Cut from Wikipedia article Oxygen, section Photosynthesis and Respiration: In nature, free oxygen is produced by the light-driven splittingof water during oxygenic photosynthesis.According to some estimates, green algaeand cyanobacteriain marine environments provide about 70% of the free oxygen produced on Earth, and the rest is produced by terrestrial plants. Other estimates of the oceanic contribution to atmospheric oxygen are higher, while some estimates are lower, suggesting oceans produce ~45% of Earth's atmospheric oxygen each year. See also Wikipedia article Oxygen Evolution. Cut from courses.lumenlearning.com article Evolution of Massive Stars:  Figure 1: Structure of an Old Massive Star. Just before its final gravitational collapse, the core of a massive star resembles an onion. The iron core is surrounded by layers of silicon and sulfur, oxygen, neon, carbon mixed with some oxygen, helium, and finally hydrogen. Outside the core, the composition is mainly hydrogen and helium. (Note that this diagram is not precisely to scale but is just meant to convey the general idea of what such a star would be like.) (credit: modification of work by ESO, Digitized Sky Survey)

The answer is fascinating. This is a rough overview; you can get better details at wikipedia’s geological history of oxygen. First you should recognize that nature likes things in their lowest energy state. Free oxygen is not energetically favorable, meaning it is hard to separate out from things like water H2O, carbon dioxide CO2, or rust. On the other hand, it is easy to take it out of the air by burning something or absorbing it into water or rusting something. So nature doesn’t want to have oxygen in the atmosphere, and most planets (including Earth for the first 4 billion years) have little or no oxygen in their atmosphere. Then along comes plant life. Plants, especially on land, get so much energy from sunlight that they can afford to do things that cost them energy. Plants also need building material. Plants are made up of a lot of carbon (that’s what burns when you burn wood). Where are they to get the carbon from? The answer is the air. About 650 million years ago, plant life exploded on the planet, and built trees and other plants by separating CO2, keeping the Carbon C, and releasing the oxygen O2. As a result, the oxygen content of air shot up (from too little for us to breathe to 35%, which is way more than today’s 20%. That oxygen-rich atmosphere helped land life get a head start (because so much oxygen made it easier to burn fuel when eating plants) and allowed life to grow very big (like dinosaurs and 6″ flying insects). See graph below from wikimedia commons.  (Clarification: photosynthetic (sun-based) life started in the oceans much earlier, and we got the initial oxygen appearing as early as 1 billion years into Earth’s 4.55 billion year life so far. It took a long time for the small amount of oxygen production to finally saturate the oceans and rust all the stuff it could rust, and then at 650 million years, all the oxygen production went into the air, making our life possible.)

All of the oxygen on Earth was made long ago in the cores of stars. All stars spend the early parts of their lives fusing hydrogen into helium, and when that is mostly gone they start fusing the helium into heavier elements including oxygen, carbon, silicon, iron, nickel, nitrogen, and all of the others. Stars that are somewhat bigger than our sun eventually end their lives in tremendous explosions called supernovas, scattering these chemical elements out across space in huge clouds. A part of one of these huge clouds of gas and stellar debris eventually collapsed to form our solar system. In the process some of it condensed to form Earth, which is why our planet is rich in all of the elements I mentioned above. Oxygen is actually the third most-abundant element in the Universe today, right after hydrogen and helium. Oxygen is also the most abundant element in Earth’s crust. If you pick up any random rock, that rock is more than half oxygen by weight! And it all came from ancient stardust.

As I understand it, the element Oxygen (atomic O) was formed in large stars and subsequent supernovae explosions in the vicinity of what would be our solar system sometime between 6Billion and 9 billion years ago. Oxygen16 is one alpha particle higher than Carbon12. After a large star burns almost all of its H to He at the star’s core, it stars another fusion reaction called the “triple alpha process” where 3 He atoms (alpha particles) fuse through a Be8 intermediary into a Carbon12 nucleus. Once the He is exhausted at the core of the large star (H is burning to He in an outer layer), the Carbon12 that has accumulated begins to burn with additional He4 into Oxygen. This “onion-skin” process (nucleosynthesis) continues all the way up to Iron. WHen that happens, the star explodes in a few minutes in a Supernova explosion which spews the elements throughout the region (including the oxygen and carbon). In other words, we can thank a long-dead star for nearly all the atoms that make up our bodies and our world (except Hydrogen and maybe some He which formed at the moment of the Big Bang). Molecular Oxygen is formed the way the other experts below have mentioned. However, it might be worthwhile to mention that the Photosynthetic reaction center is an incredibly wonderful “sculpture” with a “crown porphyrin” surrounding a magnesium atom. It is incredibly efficient in converting the energy of sunlight into sugars and larger molecules (like cellulose - fiber for us). Also, it might be worthwhile mentioning that nearly all the mass of plants is water and the carbon dioxide from the air (and a little Hydrogen from water - the oxygen in water is released to the air as a “waste product” from the plant - “lucky” for us). Without CO2 we would be dead very quickly (no food for plants or for us). The recent increase in the last 50 years or so in CO2 levels is greening the planet and in particular the desert areas because the plants exchange water for CO2. With higher ambient concentrations of CO2 in the air, they do not need to loses as much water through transpiration. THank-God for the increase in CO2!!!

I’m trying (I’ve taken up prayer too) not to be an ass. I’m sure I misunderstand the question? Normally I’d say green stuff. It would be a proper answer, but again, a bit short (I don’t have many friends). Are you asking where does the oxygen we breathe come from? If so, the green stuff. Update: I’m in a rough patch right now. I apologies if I was short. Oxygen is very reactive and is usually not available for what we animal’s do with it. Photosynthesis creates O2 - and what a game changer that was. I just want to take a second to make those appreciate how long it took to “rust” all the Iron out of the oceans! About a billion years. Then o2 started to leak into the atmosphere. Then somehow a clever little life form realized that this has a bit of a kick to it. O2 is waste for plants…a boom for animals. Again, I’m going through it it right now, I’m sorry.

There are many sources of oxygen, but a few are the breathing of plants and animals and the decomposition of dead plant and animal material.The main source of atmospheric free oxygen is photosynthesis, which produces sugars and free oxygen from carbon dioxide and water. Most of Earth's oxygen comes from the tiny ocean plants – called phytoplankton – they live near the water's surface and drift with the currents. Like all plants, they photosynthesize – which means, they use sunlight and carbon dioxide to make food. And a by-product of photosynthesis is oxygen. In the process of photosynthesis, phytoplankton release oxygen into the water. Half of the world's oxygen is produced via phytoplankton photosynthesis. The other half is produced via photosynthesis on land by trees, shrubs, grasses, and other plants.

If we want to go very far back, a large portion of stars form oxygen from helium near the end of their lives, through the CNO (carbon-nitrogen-oxygen) cycle. Our own Sun will form it at its core in its final days. Larger stars form it more readily. Although there was no oxygen at the beginning of the universe, it is the third most abundant element today, thanks to stars. The first two are hydrogen and helium. Oxygen is also the most abundant element in Earth’s crust. It combines with other elements to produce materials such as silicates, which we generally call rocks. It also combines with hydrogen to make water. Because oxygen is so reactive, it originally remained sequestered in the Earth’s crust and in the form of other molecules like carbon dioxide. Early life did not breathe free atmospheric oxygen, but some produced it as a byproduct of photosynthesis. Cyanobacteria eventually became very efficient at this, reproducing massively. For a long time, the free oxygen produced by life continued to react with the material in Earth’s crust and was sequestered. Eventually, the crust reached its saturation limit, and the oxygen began to accumulate in the atmosphere. Oxygen is very reactive — a poison really. In some ways we are all being poisoned by the oxygen we require to live, which contributes to our aging. When the atmosphere first became oxygenated in the Great Oxygenation Event due to photosynthesis, much of the life on Earth was wiped out by this poison. New lifeforms, however, emerged to tolerate the oxygen and use it as an effective way to extract energy from food. This turned out to be a boon for life as it freed it from direct dependence on sunlight and less efficient fermentation and anaerobic respiration processes.

Almost all of it had come from plants. Originally Earth;s atmosphere contained only trace oxygen and a great deal of CO2, nitrogen, methane and traces of other gases like O2. Then about 3.5 billion years ago there evolved a colonial bacterium which had captured another organisms we know as chloroplasts —the chemical factories within cells that take CO2 and give off oxygen as waste from their energy ‘factories’ (we have the fossils and they exist today as well). They are cyanobacteria, “cyano” means in the absence of oxygen, Their fossils are known as stromatolites. Over the next 1.5 Billion years their waste O@ accumulated in the oceans and atmosphere. About 1 billion years ago the ancestors of plants and fungi evolved a symbiotic relationship and the plants captured chloroplasts (the cyanobacteria) which continued to perform their age-old function; taking CO2 and making energy and giving off O2 as waste. Today cyanobacteria are uncommon, but ocean algae, grass and trees produce the world’s oxygen.

It has always been there. How do you think you can breathe? As you breathe, you consume some of the oxygen and the other gases just dilute it a little so that you do not overload your body with pure oxygen. These gases just go in and out with no change. The oxygen you consume has some of it converted to Carbon Dioxide and this goes out with a fair amount of the oxygen you inhale. If it did not CPR would not work. The exhaled CO2 then wanders around in the atmosphere and much of it is “inhaled” by trees and plants which synthesize it to use the carbon content and release the oxygen content back to the atmosphere so you can breathe it again. Mother Nature is fairly clever isn’t she, but you already knew this didn’t you David.

Oxygen arrived on Earth in the form of water, carbon dioxide, and other molecules containing oxygen. The oxygen stayed in these molecules until prokaryotic microorganisms on the early Earth evolved the ability to break carbon dioxide up into its constituent elements using photosynthesis. The microorganisms (which are made up primarily of hydrocarbons and water) needed the carbon to make copies of themselves via cell division. The oxygen was a waste product which they released into Earth's early atmosphere (which contained no free oxygen to start with). Photosynthetic microorganisms eventually produced enough free oxygen to make it possible for more complex multi cellular organisms to develop and prosper.

The oxygen in our air comes from the process of a nuclear fusion reaction of carbon and helium atoms occurring within the heart of a star, called Stellar nucleosynthesis It is a process by which all heavier elements of larger atomic numbers are formed (beyond helium). However free oxygen is a rarity, as it is highly reactive, bonded with hydrogen to form water (H2O) or within rocks as silicates and carbonates. Oxygen is the most abundant element found on Earth! The free oxygen in our atmosphere is produced from the biological process of photosynthesis the process which evolved within simple organisms that evolved on Earth around 3 billion years ago. They are the ancestors of our modern day plants.

Depends on what you mean by oxygen. Oxygen atoms are produced in stars. Michael McClennen's answer explains it. Oxygen atoms are present in a variety of molecules, including water (H2O), and carbon dioxide (CO2). If you are thinking about the oxygen people breathe, you are talking about the oxygen molecule (or oxygen gas) (O2). That comes from bacteria and in more recent times, plants. It originally came from various single-celled organisms. Some organisms managed to evolve photosynthesis which produces oxygen gas (O2) from carbon dioxide (CO2). Oxygen molecule is toxic to a lot of organisms - that event probably wiped of over 95% of all life on Earth. Read it here: Great Oxygenation Event - Wikipedia.

Evaporation and transpiration. WATER! Supposedly, evaporation/transpiration produce water vapor:  Boil some water on the stove. Put your hand over the boiling pot. It doesn’t get even moist not does the vent hood. Bread or sponges place above open pots don’t get damp/wet irrespective of the amount of time they remain above the evaporating water. Those tiny bubbles are the bottom of the pot: Hydrogen and oxygen atoms which cannot ignite when they break the water’s surface unless they are in the presence of heated carbon (as is the case with your charcoal grille). Water molecules separate into separate atoms - the oxygen atoms bond to form O2 and hydrogen atoms also enter the atmosphere to provide both energy and life-giving oxygen to the organisms that require it.

Most of the oxygen in the air comes from plants. Plants go through photosynthesis in order to produce glucose and oxygen is a byproduct of this reaction. The balanced chemical equation for this process is 6CO2 + 6H2O + sunlight= C6H12O6 + 6O2. Since cellular respiration is just the opposite of this( Minus sunlight and plus ATP on the product side) we take in oxygen and glucose for energy and produce carbon dioxide and water. Plants then use the carbon dioxide we make to produce more oxygen. The reason why we can’t just eat food to get water via cellular respiration is because we use more water to break down food than we produce.

In stars, nitrogen is fused with hydrogen to form oxygen (stellar nucleosynthesis). When starts explode, elemental oxygen (along with many other elements are ejected) and the oxygen can chemically react with a wide variety of other elements. That material may form planets and there will be a variety of oxidized materials (silicon, iron, etc.) in the planetary crust. There might even be water. On Earth, we have trees that absorb [math]CO_2[/math] from the atmosphere and use sunlight to produce sugars and waste oxygen ([math]O_2[/math]). We also have oxygen locked up in water and minerals in the earth’s crust, as well as the biomass on the planet.

Well we all know that oxygen came from dying stars after supernovae during the early days of our solar system. But how is oxygen being produced on Earth in the present time…. That`s mainly because of millions of phytoplanktons freely floating in water bodies all around the Earth. These microscopic photosynthetic organisms along with under water kelp forests (composed of large algae) are the major source of billions of gallon of dissolved oxygen in water. Trees and other terrestrial plants are also contributing to the oxygen cycle through the same process of photosynthesis. Hope this helped….

Photosynthesis. Consider turning carbon dioxide and water into glucose: 6CO2 + 6H2O + energy = C6H12O6 (glucose) + 6O2. Pretty much every time plants synthesize something, oxygen is left over. There’s a word for that: toxic waste. It’s actually toxic to many organisms. That’s why you have to get tetanus shots - the tetanus bacilli thrive in deep, oxygen poor wounds. Eventually organisms arose who could run the reaction in reverse. C6H12O6 (glucose) + 6O2 = 6CO2 + 6H2O + energy. That’s us. Those poor, hard-working plants make chemicals, and we steal them to extract energy. You thief. We used to say how fortunate it was that the earth has an oxygen-rich atmosphere that can support life. Now we understand the earth has an oxygen-rich atmosphere because it supports life.

Science seams to have no answer. as for it being produced from photosynthesis that is correct if you first had water, you can’t have plants with out water H2O? So where did it come from to make H2O water, the only answer i can get is from collapsed stars, but how? and this is the case with a lot of other elements that is needed to sustain life, that is why they have invented dark mater, the plane fact like a lot of things, they don’t know, or wont give in to what created life in the first place.

It is a myth that forests supply a large portion of the oxygen of earth. As a matter of fact, many forests consume just as much oxygen as they produce. In fact, a huge portion of the oxygen that you are breathing today comes from photosynthetic plankton from eras ago. It would take an extremely long time to even put a slight dent in the world’s oxygen, even if no oxygen were to be produced, due to these little guys and all the oxygen that they produced a long time ago.

If you're looking for the really really old source of oxygen, it's produced as starts fuse certain elements, as outlined in Oxygen. If you're looking for the terrestrial answer, the majority of free oxygen on the planet is produced by photosynthesis.  Without photosynthesis occuring global oxygen levels would fall as oxygen reacts to from CO2, rust, and other compounds.  The early earth did not have free oxygen.  It took early bacteria and algae a long time to produce the oxygen levels we have today.

Russia..im pretty sure a majority of the oxygen is created from a massive forrest in northern russia. Its either that or plankton, or algea. Looking at this statment seems like i got it backwards, but im no cheater! Its gotta be plankton… Im going with plankton. I think the rest is made in a forrest in russia. Beer is not good for the brain.. Plankton! 70% of the oxygen on earth is made by phytoplankton. boom….Completely wrong about Russia, dont know were i got that from..

The oxygen gas we breathe is mostly produced by photosynthesis by plants, phytoplankton, etc. Some minor amounts are made by electrolysis of water into oxygen and hydrogen gases, although if hydrogen fuel cells become dominant in the future, then alongside the huge amount hydrogen fuel, we'd be producing oxygen gas alongside it (which will of course get consumed when the hydrogen fuel is consumed). …I'm going to leave it to the nuclear chemists about where elemental oxygen comes from (as I understand, from several generations of stars that undergo fusion of progressively heavier atoms).

The Earth’s has come when the world was been formed due to the explosion in the sun million of years ago. As at that time the earth only was just a part of lava and nothing else so it has helium in it . After it was getting cooled the water also known as the H2O has started forming in the earth . That time the oxygen from the water in a little amount got detached due to the heat and the evaporation of water due to the heat. This caused the formation of the oxygen .

Oxygen much like all other elements are made in the core of stars and it's directly related to how stars get the energy to “burn” Stars start out by fusing hydrogen atoms into helium.When hydrogen is depleted the star starts burning helium. Three (3) helium atoms fuse to make carbon. Four(4) helium atoms fuse to make oxygen.The process keeps going until Iron (Fe).Heavier elements are made if/when a star goes nova.This short video might explain it a little better. There are a lot of other videos on this topic.

Well, we could say that the [math] O_{2} [/math] molecules in the air were released by “green” organisms (containing chlorophyll) in the process of photosynthesis. But that doesn’t really answer the question, does it, as they don’t actually “make” oxygen—they just release it from other compounds that enter the bio-chemical process. So if you’re asking where the oxygen itself was “crated”, the answer is: in the cores of 1st generation stars via thermonuclear reaction; as all of the lighter elements were. All the oxygen we’ve got here, no matter how chemically bound, was here since the Earth formed some 4.5 billion years ago (and the atoms are rather older even than that).

Oxygen, like all bar the few lightest elements, was formed in a star which subsequently exploded. The oxygen came to Earth combined with other elements. Early life got it’s energy from photosynthesis which broke apart carbon dioxide, poisoning the atmosphere with oxygen. Animals evolved to make use of the oxygen, recombining it with carbon to make carbon dioxide.

Oxygen is one of the elements created by stars, all the oxygen here was blasted into space by supernovae, with our solar system subsequently formed from the debris of these earlier stars. If you mean why do we have free oxygen in our atmosphere then that’s all been put there by photosynthetic (green) plant life, which uses carbon dioxide, water and sunlight to produce its own food, releasing the oxygen as an unwanted byproduct of photosynthesis. Oxygen is too reactive to exist naturally in our atmosphere.

During the early days of earth, the atmosphere was reducing in nature. The main gases were methane, hydrogen,nitrogen, etc. At that time,the oxygen was present in the form of compounds and there was little or no free oxygen. The primitive life form was anaerobic but then, there was an evolutionary change and some organisms started releasing oxygen through photosynthesis. These oxygen releasing organisms were cyanobacteria. The new gas ,oxygen proved to be fatal for other living organisms and due to decrease in competition, the population of cyanobacteria exploded. As a result, the oxygen level increased gradually over millions of years and the reducing atmosphere became oxidising (as we know it to be today) Note: any suggestions or corrections are welcome. ☮

Our sun starts with hydrogen and fuse to high elements. Carbon is fused before oxygen see at min numbers. So as soon as oxygen is fused it react with hydrogen and carbon making water and co2. So oxygen doesn't exists in nature. All our oxygen is produced from co2 by plants. O2 don't exist in universe as other elements exist. This is one of the puzzles in forming life. Interesting sequential process of life formation. Water is made in the sun and brought to earth.

Do you mean the element oxygen or the gas oxygen. The element was created in the cores of the early generation stars and was dispersed through the galaxy in supernovae. Second generation stars and planets ended up with that star-stuff in them. Our atmosphere was not always so oxygen rich. It was a reducing atmosphere for the first couple of billion years or so until green plants evolved. Only then did animal life start evolving.

The oxygen cycle is the biogeochemical transitions of oxygen atoms between different oxidation states in ions, oxides, and molecules through redox reactions within and between the spheres/reservoirs of the planet Earth. The word oxygen in the literature typically refers to the most common oxygen allotrope, elemental/diatomic oxygen (O2), as it is a common product or reactant of many biogeochemical redox reactions within the cycle. Processes within the oxygen cycle are considered to be biological or geological and are evaluated as either a source (O2 production) or sink (O2 consumption).

Oxygen likely first came from ocean algae. Early algae began performing photosynthesis absorbing CO2 in the oceans and releasing O2. Eventually, the Earth’s oceans became saturated with O2 and then the O2 was released into the air in what was likely a fairly quick and catastrophic event.

Q: Where does the oxygen come from Earth? I think it’s mostly basically from the Oxygen Holocaust about 2.45 billion years ago. Life has produced most of the Earth’s free oxygen, particularly as of about 700 million years ago when the earliest plants developed. Here is the oxygen content of the Earth’s atmosphere over Earth’s history. The current level (21%) is indicated by the dotted red line.

Cyano-bacteria were the first and simplest organisms capable of photo-synthesis, producing the oxygen from the abundance of carbon-dioxide in the atmosphere which existed in the earth’s early formation. Later of course, other plants developed, but cyano bacteria still exist and flourish in warm waters.

Scientists estimate that 50-80% of the oxygen production on Earth comes from the ocean. The majority of this production is from oceanic plankton — drifting plants, algae, and some bacteria that can photosynthesize.

The evidence seems to point to Cyanobacteria during the ‘Great Oxygenation Event’. They can still be found in ancient ‘living’ structure like stromatolites which are quite rare now but thought to have been quite extensive around the Earth.

As a natural source plants are the good source of oxygen. They produce food for us by photosynthesis and give us oxygen as a byproduct of this great chemical process. As a chemical compound barium peroxide is a good source of oxygen. It decomposes to barium oxide and oxygen. 2BaO2------->2BaO +O2 After getting oxygen the byproduct BaO again reacts with air producing barium peroxide which on heating gives oxygen and the process continues.
